question: A vehicle that uses hydrogen as its onboard fuel for motive power is cosidered which, Flex-fuel or Bi-fuel?

nodes.instruction: Retrieve definitions and differences between Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles.
nodes.output:
Flex-fuel vehicles, also known as dual-fuel vehicles, are designed to run on more than one fuel, usually gasoline blended with either ethanol or methanol fuel. Both fuels are stored in the same common tank, and the engine is capable of burning any proportion of the resulting blend in the combustion chamber. This is achieved through automatic adjustments to fuel injection and spark timing based on the actual blend detected by a fuel composition sensor. Flex-fuel vehicles are common in the United States, with a large fleet of cars and light trucks in operation.

On the other hand, bi-fuel vehicles have multifuel engines capable of running on two separate fuels, such as gasoline or diesel and an alternate fuel like natural gas, LPG, or hydrogen. These vehicles have the capability to switch back and forth from one fuel to the other, either manually or automatically. The two fuels are stored in separate tanks, and the engine runs on one fuel at a time, or in some cases, both fuels are used in unison.

In summary, the main difference between flex-fuel and bi-fuel vehicles lies in the storage and usage of the alternative fuel. Flex-fuel vehicles store both fuels in the same tank and can use any proportion of the blend, while bi-fuel vehicles store the fuels in separate tanks and run on one fuel at a time. Both types of vehicles offer the flexibility to use alternative fuels, contributing to the reduction of emissions and dependence on traditional gasoline.

nodes.instruction: Retrieve characteristics of vehicles that use hydrogen as onboard fuel for motive power.
nodes.output:
1. Hydrogen vehicles can use either internal combustion engines or fuel cells to convert hydrogen into mechanical energy for propulsion.
2. Japan has a network of hydrogen filling stations along its roadsides to support hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, with approximately 80 stations as of May 2016.
3. The United States has been conducting research and development into hydrogen fuel cells and hydrogen production since the Energy Policy Act of 1992.
4. Fuel cell vehicles are classified as zero-emissions vehicles, emitting only water and heat, but may centralize pollutants at the site of hydrogen production.
5. The BMW Hydrogen 7 is a limited production hydrogen internal combustion engine vehicle that can also run on gasoline.
6. Hydrogen can be used as a power source for aircraft, either through burning in an engine or through a fuel cell to generate electricity.
7. Thermonuclear weapons, colloquially known as hydrogen bombs, use nuclear fusion of hydrogen isotopes to greatly increase explosive power.
8. Bi-fuel vehicles are capable of running on two fuels, such as gasoline or diesel and an alternate fuel like natural gas, LPG, or hydrogen.

nodes.instruction: Compare the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles against the definitions of Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles to determine classification.
nodes.output: Based on the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles and the definitions of flex-fuel and bi-fuel vehicles, hydrogen vehicles can be classified as bi-fuel vehicles. This is because hydrogen vehicles have the capability to run on two separate fuels - hydrogen and either gasoline or diesel. Additionally, hydrogen vehicles store the fuels in separate tanks and have the capability to switch back and forth from one fuel to the other, which aligns with the definition of bi-fuel vehicles. Therefore, hydrogen vehicles can be classified as bi-fuel vehicles based on their characteristics and capabilities.

retrieved_passages:
Hydrogen vehicle
A hydrogen vehicle is a vehicle that uses hydrogen as its onboard fuel for motive power. Hydrogen vehicles include hydrogen fueled space rockets, as well as automobiles and other transportation vehicles. The power plants of such vehicles convert the chemical energy of hydrogen to mechanical energy either by burning hydrogen in an internal combustion engine, or by reacting hydrogen with oxygen in a fuel cell to run electric motors. Widespread use of hydrogen for fueling transportation is a key element of a proposed hydrogen economy.

Flexible-fuel vehicle
A flexible-fuel vehicle (FFV) or dual-fuel vehicle (colloquially called a flex-fuel vehicle) is an alternative fuel vehicle with an internal combustion engine designed to run on more than one fuel, usually gasoline blended with either ethanol or methanol fuel, and both fuels are stored in the same common tank. Modern flex-fuel engines are capable of burning any proportion of the resulting blend in the combustion chamber as fuel injection and spark timing are adjusted automatically according to the actual blend detected by a fuel composition sensor. Flex-fuel vehicles are distinguished from bi-fuel vehicles, where two fuels are stored in separate tanks and the engine runs on one fuel at a time, for example, compressed natural gas (CNG), liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), or hydrogen.

Flexible-fuel vehicles in the United States
Flexible-fuel vehicles in the United States are the second largest flex-fuel fleet in the world after Brazil, and there were about 17.4 million flex-fuel cars and light trucks in operation by the end of 2014. Despite the growing fleet of E85 flex-fuel vehicles, actual use of ethanol fuel is limited due to the lack of E85 refueling infrastructure and also because many American flex-fuel car owners were not aware they owned an E85 flex-fuel vehicle. Flex-fuel vehicles are common in the Midwest, where corn is a major crop and is the primary feedstock for ethanol fuel production. Also the U.S. government has been using flex-fuel vehicles for many years.

Bi-fuel vehicle
Bi-fuel vehicles or otherwise known as dual fuel are vehicles with multifuel engines capable of running on two fuels. On internal combustion engines one fuel is gasoline or diesel, and the other is an alternate fuel such as natural gas (CNG), LPG, or hydrogen. The two fuels are stored in separate tanks and the engine runs on one fuel at a time in some cases, in others both fuels are used in unison. Bi-fuel vehicles have the capability to switch back and forth from gasoline or diesel to the other fuel, manually or automatically.

Hydrogen highway (Japan)
Japan's hydrogen highway is a network of hydrogen filling stations placed along roadsides that provide fuel for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (HFCV). An HFCV is a vehicle that uses a fuel cell to convert hydrogen energy into electrical energy. The hydrogen that is used in fuel cell vehicles can be made using fossil or renewable resources. The hydrogen highway is necessary for HFCVs to be used. HFCV reduce tailpipe emissions of greenhouse gases. By May 2016, there were approximately 80 hydrogen fueling stations in Japan.

United States hydrogen policy
The principle of a fuel cell was discovered by Christian Friedrich Schönbein in 1838, and the first fuel cell was constructed by Sir William Robert Grove in 1839. The fuel cells made at this time were most similar to today's phosphoric acid fuel cells. Most hydrogen fuel cells today are of the proton exchange membrane (PEM) type. A PEM converts the chemical energy released during the electrochemical reaction of hydrogen and oxygen into electrical energy. The Energy Policy Act of 1992 was the first national legislation that called for large-scale hydrogen research. A five-year program was conducted that investigated the production of hydrogen from renewable energy sources and the feasibility of existing natural gas pipelines to carry hydrogen. It also called for the research into hydrogen storage systems for electric vehicles and the development of fuel cells suitable to power an electric motor vehicle.

Fuel cell vehicle
A fuel cell vehicle (FCV) or fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV) is a type of electric vehicle which uses a fuel cell, instead of a battery, or in combination with a battery or supercapacitor, to power its on-board electric motor. Fuel cells in vehicles generate electricity to power the motor, generally using oxygen from the air and compressed hydrogen. Most fuel cell vehicles are classified as zero-emissions vehicles that emit only water and heat. As compared with internal combustion vehicles, hydrogen vehicles centralize pollutants at the site of the hydrogen production, where hydrogen is typically derived from reformed natural gas. Transporting and storing hydrogen may also create pollutants.

BMW Hydrogen 7
The BMW Hydrogen 7 is a limited production hydrogen internal combustion engine vehicle built from 2005-2007 by German automobile manufacturer BMW. The car is based on BMW’s traditional gasoline-powered BMW 7 Series (E65) line of vehicles, and more specifically the 760Li. It uses the same 6 litre V-12 motor as does the 760i and 760Li; however, it has been modified to also allow for the combustion of hydrogen as well as gasoline, making it a bivalent engine. Unlike many other current hydrogen powered vehicles like those being produced by Honda, General Motors, and Daimler AG - which use fuel cell technology and hydrogen to produce electricity to power the vehicle - the BMW Hydrogen 7 burns the hydrogen in an internal combustion engine.

Hydrogen-powered aircraft
A hydrogen-powered aircraft is an aeroplane that uses hydrogen fuel as a power source. Hydrogen can either be burned in some kind of jet engine, or other kind of internal combustion engine, or can be used to power a fuel cell to generate electricity to power a propeller.

Thermonuclear weapon
A thermonuclear weapon is a second-generation nuclear weapon design using a secondary nuclear fusion stage consisting of implosion tamper, fusion fuel, and sparkplug which is bombarded by the energy released by the detonation of a primary fission bomb within, compressing the fuel material (tritium, deuterium or lithium deuteride) and causing a fusion reaction. Some advanced designs use fast neutrons produced by this second stage to ignite a third fast fission or fusion stage. The fission bomb and fusion fuel are placed near each other in a special radiation-reflecting container called a radiation case that is designed to contain x-rays for as long as possible. The result is greatly increased explosive power when compared to single-stage fission weapons. The device is colloquially referred to as a hydrogen bomb or, an H-bomb, because it employs the fusion of isotopes of hydrogen.

China National Aviation Fuel
China National Aviation Fuel Group Corporation (CNAF) is a Chinese state-owned enterprise. The company owned 51% stake of China National Aviation Fuel Supply Co., Ltd. (), one of the largest jet fuel supplier of China. China National Aviation Fuel Group was ranked 484th in 2016 Fortune Global 500 list.

nodes.instruction: Compare the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles against the definitions of Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles to determine classification.
nodes.output: Based on the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles and the definitions of flex-fuel and bi-fuel vehicles, it can be determined that hydrogen fuel vehicles would fall under the category of bi-fuel vehicles. This is because hydrogen vehicles use hydrogen as their onboard fuel, which is an alternate fuel, and can run on hydrogen as well as gasoline or diesel. Therefore, based on the storage of fuels and the ability to run on multiple fuels, hydrogen fuel vehicles would be classified as bi-fuel vehicles.

Bi-fuel vehicle
Bi-fuel vehicles or otherwise known as dual fuel are vehicles with multifuel engines capable of running on two fuels. On internal combustion engines one fuel is gasoline or diesel, and the other is an alternate fuel such as natural gas (CNG), LPG, or hydrogen. The two fuels are stored in separate tanks and the engine runs on one fuel at a time in some cases, in others both fuels are used in unison. Bi-fuel vehicles have the capability to switch back and forth from gasoline or diesel to the other fuel, manually or automatically.

Hydrogen highway (Japan)
Japan's hydrogen highway is a network of hydrogen filling stations placed along roadsides that provide fuel for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (HFCV). An HFCV is a vehicle that uses a fuel cell to convert hydrogen energy into electrical energy. The hydrogen that is used in fuel cell vehicles can be made using fossil or renewable resources. The hydrogen highway is necessary for HFCVs to be used. HFCV reduce tailpipe emissions of greenhouse gases. By May 2016, there were approximately 80 hydrogen fueling stations in Japan.

United States hydrogen policy
The principle of a fuel cell was discovered by Christian Friedrich Schönbein in 1838, and the first fuel cell was constructed by Sir William Robert Grove in 1839. The fuel cells made at this time were most similar to today's phosphoric acid fuel cells. Most hydrogen fuel cells today are of the proton exchange membrane (PEM) type. A PEM converts the chemical energy released during the electrochemical reaction of hydrogen and oxygen into electrical energy. The Energy Policy Act of 1992 was the first national legislation that called for large-scale hydrogen research. A five-year program was conducted that investigated the production of hydrogen from renewable energy sources and the feasibility of existing natural gas pipelines to carry hydrogen. It also called for the research into hydrogen storage systems for electric vehicles and the development of fuel cells suitable to power an electric motor vehicle.

Fuel cell vehicle
A fuel cell vehicle (FCV) or fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV) is a type of electric vehicle which uses a fuel cell, instead of a battery, or in combination with a battery or supercapacitor, to power its on-board electric motor. Fuel cells in vehicles generate electricity to power the motor, generally using oxygen from the air and compressed hydrogen. Most fuel cell vehicles are classified as zero-emissions vehicles that emit only water and heat. As compared with internal combustion vehicles, hydrogen vehicles centralize pollutants at the site of the hydrogen production, where hydrogen is typically derived from reformed natural gas. Transporting and storing hydrogen may also create pollutants.

BMW Hydrogen 7
The BMW Hydrogen 7 is a limited production hydrogen internal combustion engine vehicle built from 2005-2007 by German automobile manufacturer BMW. The car is based on BMW’s traditional gasoline-powered BMW 7 Series (E65) line of vehicles, and more specifically the 760Li. It uses the same 6 litre V-12 motor as does the 760i and 760Li; however, it has been modified to also allow for the combustion of hydrogen as well as gasoline, making it a bivalent engine. Unlike many other current hydrogen powered vehicles like those being produced by Honda, General Motors, and Daimler AG - which use fuel cell technology and hydrogen to produce electricity to power the vehicle - the BMW Hydrogen 7 burns the hydrogen in an internal combustion engine.

Hydrogen-powered aircraft
A hydrogen-powered aircraft is an aeroplane that uses hydrogen fuel as a power source. Hydrogen can either be burned in some kind of jet engine, or other kind of internal combustion engine, or can be used to power a fuel cell to generate electricity to power a propeller.

Thermonuclear weapon
A thermonuclear weapon is a second-generation nuclear weapon design using a secondary nuclear fusion stage consisting of implosion tamper, fusion fuel, and sparkplug which is bombarded by the energy released by the detonation of a primary fission bomb within, compressing the fuel material (tritium, deuterium or lithium deuteride) and causing a fusion reaction. Some advanced designs use fast neutrons produced by this second stage to ignite a third fast fission or fusion stage. The fission bomb and fusion fuel are placed near each other in a special radiation-reflecting container called a radiation case that is designed to contain x-rays for as long as possible. The result is greatly increased explosive power when compared to single-stage fission weapons. The device is colloquially referred to as a hydrogen bomb or, an H-bomb, because it employs the fusion of isotopes of hydrogen.

China National Aviation Fuel
China National Aviation Fuel Group Corporation (CNAF) is a Chinese state-owned enterprise. The company owned 51% stake of China National Aviation Fuel Supply Co., Ltd. (), one of the largest jet fuel supplier of China. China National Aviation Fuel Group was ranked 484th in 2016 Fortune Global 500 list.

question: A vehicle that uses hydrogen as its onboard fuel for motive power is cosidered which, Flex-fuel or Bi-fuel?

nodes.instruction: Retrieve definitions and differences between Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles.
nodes.output:
Flex-fuel vehicles, also known as dual-fuel vehicles, are designed to run on more than one fuel, usually gasoline blended with either ethanol or methanol fuel. Both fuels are stored in the same common tank, and the engine is capable of burning any proportion of the resulting blend in the combustion chamber. This is achieved through automatic adjustments to fuel injection and spark timing based on the actual blend detected by a fuel composition sensor. In contrast, bi-fuel vehicles have multifuel engines capable of running on two separate fuels, such as gasoline or diesel and an alternate fuel like natural gas, LPG, or hydrogen. These two fuels are stored in separate tanks, and the engine runs on one fuel at a time, with the capability to switch back and forth manually or automatically.

The main difference between the two types of vehicles lies in the storage and usage of the alternative fuel. Flex-fuel vehicles store both fuels in a common tank and can use any proportion of the blend, while bi-fuel vehicles store the two fuels in separate tanks and run on one fuel at a time. Both types of vehicles offer the advantage of using alternative fuels, such as ethanol, methanol, natural gas, LPG, or hydrogen, which can contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and dependence on traditional fossil fuels.

- Fuel cell vehicles are classified as zero-emissions vehicles, emitting only water and heat, and can use compressed hydrogen and oxygen from the air to generate electricity for the motor.
- The BMW Hydrogen 7 is a limited production hydrogen internal combustion engine vehicle that can also run on gasoline, using a modified V-12 motor.
- Hydrogen-powered aircraft can use hydrogen fuel to power jet engines or fuel cells to generate electricity for propellers.
- Thermonuclear weapons, colloquially known as hydrogen bombs, use nuclear fusion of isotopes of hydrogen to greatly increase explosive power.

nodes.instruction: Compare the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles against the definitions of Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles to determine classification.
nodes.output: Based on the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles and the definitions of Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles, hydrogen vehicles can be classified as bi-fuel vehicles. Additionally, the engine runs on one fuel at a time, with the capability to switch back and forth manually or automatically, which aligns with the definition of bi-fuel vehicles. Therefore, hydrogen vehicles fit the classification of bi-fuel vehicles based on their characteristics and functionality.

Both fuels are stored in the same common tank, and the engine is capable of burning any proportion of the resulting blend in the combustion chamber. This is achieved through automatic adjustments to fuel injection and spark timing based on the actual blend detected by a fuel composition sensor. Flex-fuel vehicles are common in the United States, with a large fleet of cars and light trucks in operation.

On the other hand, bi-fuel vehicles have multifuel engines capable of running on two separate fuels, such as gasoline or diesel and an alternate fuel like natural gas, LPG, or hydrogen. These vehicles have the capability to switch back and forth from one fuel to the other, either manually or automatically. The two fuels are stored in separate tanks, and the engine runs on one fuel at a time, or in some cases, both fuels are used in unison.

In summary, the main difference between flex-fuel and bi-fuel vehicles lies in the storage and usage of the alternative fuel. Flex-fuel vehicles store both fuels in the same tank and can use any proportion of the blend, while bi-fuel vehicles store the fuels in separate tanks and run on one fuel at a time.

nodes.instruction: Retrieve characteristics of vehicles that use hydrogen as onboard fuel for motive power.
nodes.output:
- Hydrogen vehicles can use either internal combustion engines or fuel cells to convert hydrogen into mechanical energy for propulsion.
- Japan has a network of hydrogen filling stations along its roadsides to support hydrogen fuel cell vehicles.
- The United States has been conducting research and development into hydrogen as a fuel source for electric vehicles since the 1990s.
- Fuel cell vehicles are considered zero-emissions vehicles, emitting only water and heat, but the production and transportation of hydrogen may create pollutants.
- The BMW Hydrogen 7 is a limited production hydrogen internal combustion engine vehicle that can also run on gasoline.
- Hydrogen can be used as a power source for aircraft, either through combustion in an engine or through a fuel cell to generate electricity.
- Thermonuclear weapons, colloquially known as hydrogen bombs, use nuclear fusion of hydrogen isotopes to create a powerful explosion.
- Bi-fuel vehicles are capable of running on two different fuels, such as gasoline or diesel and an alternate fuel like natural gas, LPG, or hydrogen.

nodes.instruction: Compare the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles against the definitions of Flex-fuel and Bi-fuel vehicles to determine classification.
nodes.output: Based on the characteristics of hydrogen fuel vehicles and the definitions of flex-fuel and bi-fuel vehicles, hydrogen vehicles can be classified as bi-fuel vehicles. This is because hydrogen vehicles have the capability to run on two separate fuels - hydrogen and either gasoline or diesel. Additionally, hydrogen vehicles store the fuels in separate tanks and can switch back and forth from one fuel to the other, which aligns with the definition of bi-fuel vehicles. Therefore, hydrogen vehicles share the characteristics and functionality of bi-fuel vehicles, making them a suitable classification within this category.

retrieved_passages:
Hydrogen vehicle
A hydrogen vehicle is a vehicle that uses hydrogen as its onboard fuel for motive power. Hydrogen vehicles include hydrogen fueled space rockets, as well as automobiles and other transportation vehicles. The power plants of such vehicles convert the chemical energy of hydrogen to mechanical energy either by burning hydrogen in an internal combustion engine, or by reacting hydrogen with oxygen in a fuel cell to run electric motors. Widespread use of hydrogen for fueling transportation is a key element of a proposed hydrogen economy.

Flexible-fuel vehicle
A flexible-fuel vehicle (FFV) or dual-fuel vehicle (colloquially called a flex-fuel vehicle) is an alternative fuel vehicle with an internal combustion engine designed to run on more than one fuel, usually gasoline blended with either ethanol or methanol fuel, and both fuels are stored in the same common tank. Modern flex-fuel engines are capable of burning any proportion of the resulting blend in the combustion chamber as fuel injection and spark timing are adjusted automatically according to the actual blend detected by a fuel composition sensor. Flex-fuel vehicles are distinguished from bi-fuel vehicles, where two fuels are stored in separate tanks and the engine runs on one fuel at a time, for example, compressed natural gas (CNG), liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), or hydrogen.

Flexible-fuel vehicles in the United States
Flexible-fuel vehicles in the United States are the second largest flex-fuel fleet in the world after Brazil, and there were about 17.4 million flex-fuel cars and light trucks in operation by the end of 2014. Despite the growing fleet of E85 flex-fuel vehicles, actual use of ethanol fuel is limited due to the lack of E85 refueling infrastructure and also because many American flex-fuel car owners were not aware they owned an E85 flex-fuel vehicle. Flex-fuel vehicles are common in the Midwest, where corn is a major crop and is the primary feedstock for ethanol fuel production. Also the U.S. government has been using flex-fuel vehicles for many years.

Bi-fuel vehicle
Bi-fuel vehicles or otherwise known as dual fuel are vehicles with multifuel engines capable of running on two fuels. On internal combustion engines one fuel is gasoline or diesel, and the other is an alternate fuel such as natural gas (CNG), LPG, or hydrogen. The two fuels are stored in separate tanks and the engine runs on one fuel at a time in some cases, in others both fuels are used in unison. Bi-fuel vehicles have the capability to switch back and forth from gasoline or diesel to the other fuel, manually or automatically.

Hydrogen highway (Japan)
Japan's hydrogen highway is a network of hydrogen filling stations placed along roadsides that provide fuel for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles (HFCV). An HFCV is a vehicle that uses a fuel cell to convert hydrogen energy into electrical energy. The hydrogen that is used in fuel cell vehicles can be made using fossil or renewable resources. The hydrogen highway is necessary for HFCVs to be used. HFCV reduce tailpipe emissions of greenhouse gases. By May 2016, there were approximately 80 hydrogen fueling stations in Japan.

United States hydrogen policy
The principle of a fuel cell was discovered by Christian Friedrich Schönbein in 1838, and the first fuel cell was constructed by Sir William Robert Grove in 1839. The fuel cells made at this time were most similar to today's phosphoric acid fuel cells. Most hydrogen fuel cells today are of the proton exchange membrane (PEM) type. A PEM converts the chemical energy released during the electrochemical reaction of hydrogen and oxygen into electrical energy. The Energy Policy Act of 1992 was the first national legislation that called for large-scale hydrogen research. A five-year program was conducted that investigated the production of hydrogen from renewable energy sources and the feasibility of existing natural gas pipelines to carry hydrogen. It also called for the research into hydrogen storage systems for electric vehicles and the development of fuel cells suitable to power an electric motor vehicle.

Fuel cell vehicle
A fuel cell vehicle (FCV) or fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV) is a type of electric vehicle which uses a fuel cell, instead of a battery, or in combination with a battery or supercapacitor, to power its on-board electric motor. Fuel cells in vehicles generate electricity to power the motor, generally using oxygen from the air and compressed hydrogen. Most fuel cell vehicles are classified as zero-emissions vehicles that emit only water and heat. As compared with internal combustion vehicles, hydrogen vehicles centralize pollutants at the site of the hydrogen production, where hydrogen is typically derived from reformed natural gas. Transporting and storing hydrogen may also create pollutants.

BMW Hydrogen 7
The BMW Hydrogen 7 is a limited production hydrogen internal combustion engine vehicle built from 2005-2007 by German automobile manufacturer BMW. The car is based on BMW’s traditional gasoline-powered BMW 7 Series (E65) line of vehicles, and more specifically the 760Li. It uses the same 6 litre V-12 motor as does the 760i and 760Li; however, it has been modified to also allow for the combustion of hydrogen as well as gasoline, making it a bivalent engine. Unlike many other current hydrogen powered vehicles like those being produced by Honda, General Motors, and Daimler AG - which use fuel cell technology and hydrogen to produce electricity to power the vehicle - the BMW Hydrogen 7 burns the hydrogen in an internal combustion engine.

Hydrogen-powered aircraft
A hydrogen-powered aircraft is an aeroplane that uses hydrogen fuel as a power source. Hydrogen can either be burned in some kind of jet engine, or other kind of internal combustion engine, or can be used to power a fuel cell to generate electricity to power a propeller.

Thermonuclear weapon
A thermonuclear weapon is a second-generation nuclear weapon design using a secondary nuclear fusion stage consisting of implosion tamper, fusion fuel, and sparkplug which is bombarded by the energy released by the detonation of a primary fission bomb within, compressing the fuel material (tritium, deuterium or lithium deuteride) and causing a fusion reaction. Some advanced designs use fast neutrons produced by this second stage to ignite a third fast fission or fusion stage. The fission bomb and fusion fuel are placed near each other in a special radiation-reflecting container called a radiation case that is designed to contain x-rays for as long as possible. The result is greatly increased explosive power when compared to single-stage fission weapons. The device is colloquially referred to as a hydrogen bomb or, an H-bomb, because it employs the fusion of isotopes of hydrogen.

China National Aviation Fuel
China National Aviation Fuel Group Corporation (CNAF) is a Chinese state-owned enterprise. The company owned 51% stake of China National Aviation Fuel Supply Co., Ltd. (), one of the largest jet fuel supplier of China. China National Aviation Fuel Group was ranked 484th in 2016 Fortune Global 500 list.
